content: The Act may be cited as the "Coptic Churches Accountability Act". In August 2013, Islamist-led mobs burned and destroyed Christian properties in Egypt after the government led by the Muslim Brotherhood was removed. The succeeding government, under President Sisi, announced that the army would rebuild the damaged churches at government expense. President Sisi also attended a Coptic Christian Christmas liturgy in January 2015, becoming the first Egyptian President to do so. President Sisi attended a Coptic Christian Christmas liturgy in January 2015, becoming the first Egyptian President to do so. In January 2016, he promised to restore all churches damaged in the 2013 sectarian violence, expressing apologies and gratitude to the Coptic community. The Egyptian military has already restored 26 out of 78 churches. The Egyptian military has restored 26 out of 78 churches damaged in the 2013 sectarian violence, with private citizens also restoring 23 buildings. A new law in August 2016 imposes burdens on church construction, leading to government approval being a trigger for violence against Christians in Egypt. In El-`Our, Minya, villagers protested the building of a new church honoring Egyptian Christians beheaded by Da'esh militants. Protestors armed with Molotov cocktails and bricks targeted the church and a Christian-owned vehicle, escalating sectarian violence. Human rights groups criticize informal reconciliation sessions for favoring outcomes unfavorable to religious minorities. The Coptic Christians, indigenous to Egypt for over 2,000 years, face challenges in protecting their religious freedom. The Coptic Church is the largest Christian community in the Middle East. US diplomatic efforts support the international protection of religious minorities and their places of worship, as mandated by the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998. The United States promotes religious freedom as a fundamental right and priority value in its engagement with other countries. The United States promotes religious freedom as a fundamental right and priority value in its engagement with other countries. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of State must provide a report on the progress of restoring Christian religious properties in Egypt after sectarian violence in August 2013 to the House of Representatives and Senate committees annually until 2021. The Secretary of State must report on the restoration or repair of Christian religious properties in Egypt, implementation of laws for church construction, and Egyptian laws on building Christian churches in annual reports on Human Rights Practices and International Religious Freedom. The Secretary of State must include in reports on Human Rights Practices and International Religious Freedom for Egypt a summary of information and a list of Christian religious properties that were damaged or destroyed. The Secretary of State must include in reports on Human Rights Practices and International Religious Freedom for Egypt a summary of information and a list of Christian religious properties that were damaged or destroyed during the sectarian violence in August 2013, including items such as artwork, manuscripts, vestments, vessels, and other artifacts.
